dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A battered wooden desk drawer groans open and light brown skinned hands with dirty fingernails twist the cap off a pint of rye whiskey and pour liquor into a coffee cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, when you fire somebody you have to stick to your guns. They screw the cap back on and lay the bottle in the draw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men might get to thinkin' that I'm weak if I take you back. The cup rises to the face of BENNY GIACOMO, late forties, with salt and pepper hair that was once jet black. Skin darker than a Louisiana Creole. He takes a sip and bares his teeth in a grimace from the whiskey. As he talks we gradually see more of him -- feet kicked up on the desk, fully in charge. A Betty Grable like pin-up girl is giving us background i more ways than one in a swimsuit and high heels on a calendar tacked to the wall: May, 1948.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I didn't tell Dupree that I'd give you your job back... All I said was that I'd be glad to talk to you if you said the right thing... Do you have something to say? A stream of cigarette smoke snakes through as the back of man's head and shoulder nudges in and shifts nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Giacomo, when one of the white guys has come off a double shift and says he's too tired to work overtime, you don't fire him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fella, what'd I tell ya? If you're not willing to give a little extra, Champion can't use you. EASY RAWLINS, thirty, handsome and a much darker brown th Giacomo, takes a drag off a Chesterfield cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Through the window behind him, a team of men pour over a partly assembled airplane, their voices echoing in the hangar that surrounds the office. Benny measures out his words one at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now... Do... you... have... something... to say? Easy swallows his frustration in silence and thinks about swallowing his pride as well. And then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my job back, Mr. Giacomo. I need to work and I need a good job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all? Easy looks down into the smoke and sits up straight to ke from bowing his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's not all... I need money so that I can pay my mortgage and eat... I need a house to live in and a place to raise children... I need to buy clothes so I can--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, fella, but I gotta get back to work... And he swings his feet down and stands up to go.   But Ea is up too, blocking his way out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ezekiel, Mr. Giacomo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Ezekiel... Ezekiel Rawlins. Benny clinches his fists and focuses on Easy's chest like fighter. And Easy rocks back on one foot ready to score a field goal with his right knee. Slowly, Giacomo's face creases into a plastic grin and he shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'cuse me, Ezekiel. And he walks around Easy, shaking his head as if amused. Easy watches him go as the low moan of the baritone sax f Duke Ellington's "Absinthe" snakes up like sin and we

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: And watch the titles, the last one reading "Two Weeks Later"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black and grey cars, Packards and Buicks from 1928 to 194 come and go on Central Avenue. Two-storied storefronts wi canvas awnings, above black men and women in hats... all a hurry. The Red Car rumbles through and then a white Cadillac convertible pulls to the curb in front of a butcher shop. Above the shop on the next floor are large partly open windows with JOPPY'S BAR in boldface letters. Inside sits Easy, back to the window reading the classified ads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T-Bone Walker's "Westside Baby" plays on the jukebox as E takes a final drag off his cigarette and stubs it out. THE FRONT PAGE of the LOS ANGELES TIMES lies face up on t table beneath the ashtray displaying A PHOTOGRAPH of a middle-aged white man and his pretty young woman companio smiling and waving. Above the happy couple is a headline "CARTER DROPS OUT OF RACE"... The caption under the photo reads "Wealthy civic leader, Todd Carter, shown here with his lovely bride-to- Daphne Monet, at a fundraiser last month was unavailable comment on his surprising withdrawal from the Mayor's rac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catch ya later, Joppy.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: SPLACK! An older black man hitching up his pants undernea a bloodstained butcher's apron has slapped his empty beer glass down hard on the counter on his way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, watch the marble!   Dammit, what'd I tell you? The fifty-year-old burly bartender leans over his big stomach checking for cracks and buffing the veiny marble of the bar with a filthy rag. Behind him is a yellow billboard from 1932 with big black letters reading "Fulle vs. Shag. 10 ROUND MAIN EVENT." We could make out more of the poster and the eight-by-ten framed boxing photos arou it if it wasn't so smoky in the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joppy, how much they payin' out there at McDonell Douglas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.   Don't it say-- His words hang as his eyes stray toward the door. Easy looks up also at THE DOORWAY which fills with the large frame of the white MAN in an off-white linen suit, his pale eyes surveying t room. Satisfied that all but two of the six tables in the tiny room are unoccupied, he smiles at Joppy and walks to the far end of the bar. Easy is surprised to see Joppy, tough ex-heavyweight that is, duck his head and smile as he makes his way over like he's answering a summons. The white man extends a friendl hand and the two of them shake like old friends and lean close to talk in private. Easy finds it hard not to watch their conversation as he takes a sip from a short glass of bourbon on the rocks. After a moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, come on over here. This here's somebody I want ya to meet... Come on. This here's a friend of mine. Easy drains his glass and stands up, then walks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Easy.   This here's Mr. Albright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can call me Dewitt, Easy.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He extends his hand and Easy shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bowing and grinning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Albright and me goes back to before the war when I was still in the fight game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Easy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever seen this guy fight...? Any time Joppy Shag stepped in the ring you knew you were gonna see some real knock-down-drag-out- fisticuffs... Where you from, Easy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkwardly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Houston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Houston... Joppy's hometown. Joppy pours Albright a straight shot of Wild Turkey and t big man sips it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I hear you need a job. Easy throws a look at Joppy, but Joppy is busy buffing th bar and putting more of Easy's business in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw yeah, Easy always tryin' to do better. Got his high school certificate from night school. He's threatenin' up on some college. And he's one of the few colored men around here who owns his own house. Shoot, he pays a mortgage every month just like a white man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Property owner, hunh? He turns up his drink and sets the empty glass down on th counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These big companies, don't give a damn, do they? He reaches in his coat pocket and produces a business car and scribbles something on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you need a job, drop by this address at seven tonight. Easy takes the card and glances at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of work you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do favors... I do favors for friends. Drop by. He nods to Joppy and walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell is that, Joppy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just somebody I know... A bidness man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kinda business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't ask him all that. He comes in here every so often looking for somebody to do a little job for him... He pays good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other words, he's a gangster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that... But if there's a dollar laying in the street I don't think he'll let a little dirt stop him from picking it up. If you worried about making that house note this month, maybe you wanna pay him a call. All them pretty girls you be with ain't gonna buy you a house.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Easy cocks his head "Are you crazy?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound like he just wants you to keep your eyes open for somebody... He'll pay you whether you see anything or not... If it was me I'd take that man's money and go on about my bidness... Ain't nothin' to worry about. Easy is still suspicious, but can't take his eyes off the card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When somebody tells me "Don't worry," I usually look down to see if my fly is open... I noticed Albright didn't bother to pay for his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little single family houses with tiny yards of St. August grass rush toward the amber Indianhead hood ornament on Easy's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duke Ellington's "Mood Indigo" plays on the radio as Easy heads for home in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DeWitt Albright reminded me of somebody I knew back in Houston. His name was Raymond Alexander but we called him Mouse... Mouse called hisself a businessman too. And I found out that I shouldn't be nowhere around when Mouse got down to his business... I learned that the hard way. A neighbor sweeps out her front porch and waves at Easy a he slows down in front of his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets out of his car and a group of children chasing a giving goat cart rides, washes past him in the street.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A MAN with an unruly head of hair and full beard pushing wheelbarrow with a double edged axe wheels up behind Easy he opens his gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to knock down some of them trees back there for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) No... Just leave the trees alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy continues up his walkway past flower beds of dahlias and wild roses and stops on his front porch to check on h African violets in a jar next to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks into his tiny living room and tosses his jacket onto the sofa. Then moves on through the kitchen and out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up a water hose and turns on the faucet, waterin and admiring his apple, avocado, pomegranate and banana trees as he lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had moved to Los Angeles right after the war with three hundred dollars and the G.I. Bill... And I liked coming home to a place that was mine... According to President Truman I had that comin' to me 'cause I had fought in 'the good war' against Hitler in Europe... But that didn't mean a damn thing to a lotta white folks including the foreman on my job... So, here I was out of work needin' thirty-two dollars to pay the mortgage... That was three days pay on my old job -- and I had about three days to get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy parks in front of a large Spanish-style building. gets out and walks to the black wrought iron entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy makes his way through the overgrown patio with roses and vines cascading down from office windows on the secon floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone is watching Easy as he looks for the right office

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small white MAN pops out from behind a hedge startling Easy. He wears a suit that also serves as a uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We only take deliveries between nine and six...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we do!   Now you'd better leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clutches a baton in his hand and swats it into his ope palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... Albright!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here to see Mr. Albright. DeWitt Albright!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your delivery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his scrawny hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an appointment -- I'm supposed to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he give you a note to come in here after hours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy only stares, hating this little man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, did he?   Because if he didn't--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, man. Next time I see him I'll just tell him you wouldn't let me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disgusted, Easy turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sizes up Easy and then points across the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like an order) Across that way to the left and down the stairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy half nods/half glares and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: At the other side of the garden Easy turns a corner and heads down concrete steps. At the bottom he opens a door leading into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks into the boiler room but turns into an empty corridor stopping at a heavy steel door at the end. He knocks. After a moment a tall and slight MAN with curl brown hair and the complexion of an East Indian opens the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short and stocky kind of Chinese-looking MAN stands against the door at the far end. The Tall Man ushers Easy into the clutter of heavy metal tools, cans of paint and cleaning solutions. A card table with two chairs sits idl The Tall Man closes the door and holds out his hand. Easy reaches to shake it but the man starts to pat Easy on his side and Easy pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man!    What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chinese Man slips a hand inside his coat and the Tall Man smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an accent) Mr. Rawlins, put your hands up a little from your sides, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your hands to yourself. I don't let no man feel on me like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chinese Man pulls some kind of weapon halfway out and takes a step forward, and the Tall Man tries to put his h against Easy's chest but Easy grabs his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Manny. He's okay. Just a little shaky. (indicating the door) Let him know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manny pushes his weapon back in his coat and knocks on th door behind him. After a moment, DeWitt Albright opens up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't want us to touch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it, Shariff. I just wanted to make sure he was solo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys can go now. Easy and I have some business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy follows Albright inside and the big man goes behind big wooden desk and puts his bone-colored shoes up next t half full bottle of Wild Turkey. On the other end of the desk a small radio scratches out the Glen Gray Orchestra' "Gotta Be This or That."

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There is a paper calendar hanging on the wall behind him with a picture of a basket of blackberries, but other tha that the room is bare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat, Mr. Rawlins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy takes a seat in a chair in front of the desk and tri not to stare at the tan leather shoulder holster under Albright's arm with the muzzle of the pistol almost reach his belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing back) Your friends, hunh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you, Easy. I need a little help? I give 'em a call... Drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albright pulls another glass from the desk drawer and pou a fresh one for Easy and fresher one for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing I like about working for myself... I always have a bottle on the table... You wanna drink with me? Fine. You don't? Door's right behind you... Joppy tells me you're a war hero... Said you went in with Patton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy nods, proud but polite, and Albright pushes him a gl of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you want the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends on what kind of job. I don't want to get mixed up in nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk out the door in the morning, Easy, and you're mixed up in something. Only thing that matters is if you're mixed up to the top or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean I don't wanna get mixed up with the law...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither one of us wants to get mixed up in that. That's just rich people trying to keep me and you in our place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs and takes a healthy swig and Easy takes a drink too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for somebody for a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes a newspaper across the desk to Easy and Easy ho it up.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER
dialogues.text: It's the front page with the photograph of the wealthy To Carter and his beautiful bride-to-be... Despite her smile there's a sadness in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daphne Monet... fiancГ©e of Todd Carter, one of the richest men in town... Been gone for two weeks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leave him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evidently... You know how it is with women, Easy... Happens to the best of us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rears back in his chair as if expecting a sign of recognition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't never heard of her before. I wouldn't know how to find a woman like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs a conspiratorial, lecher's laugh and Easy allow smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, Daphne has a predilection for the company of Negroes. She likes jazz and pigs feet and dark meat, know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The insult takes Easy off guard but he should've known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you think she might be down in Watts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure of it. But I can't go looking for her myself because I'm not of the right persuasion, so to speak. I've been asking Joppy for over a week, but all he could do was introduce me to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get a location on her. Mr. Carter wants to make up with her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls out a brown secretary-type wallet and counts out ten-dollar bills into a neat stack next to the whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred dollars, and I pay in advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy eyes the money.   All he has to do is pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just have to tell you where she is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. And keep it, you know, confidential...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He freshens Easy's drink and Easy eyes the money some mor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joppy tells me you used to frequent an illegal club down on Eighty- ninth and Central. Somebody saw Daphne there a few nights ago. You could start tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy takes a drink and looks again at the money.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JOHN'S PLACE, (MARKET)
dialogues.text: Stripped down to its dark, naked self, Central Avenue has drawn a crowd from all over town. Neon glistens off slick pomade and silk clings to the contours of simmering flesh An outrage to police even before the era of Police Chief Parker's personal crusade, a squad car sits idling while dicks in blue manhandle a brother in a grey sharkskin zoo suit, prodding and whapping with nightsticks, searching f something -- anything -- because his date is a young whit woman. A few onlookers stand back watching, but since thi white woman is not Daphne Monet, Easy only glances and wa inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy sees his fifth white MAN that day in a disheveled bu expensive dark blue suit staggering toward him, reeking o gin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, colored brother. I need you to do somethin' for me--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. What'd I tell you about hair-assing my customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy looks over to see HATTIE PARSONS, the small, brown- skinned manager of the place, glaring daggers at the drun man while watching the commotion out the window. Easy starts over toward Hattie and the drunk turns and tr to grab Easy's arm. But his desperation causes him to tri and he winds up sitting against the wall. Easy steps over him and joins Hattie at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just paid these damn cops and they still roustin' my customers. Well, that's what he gets for being with that white woman.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She walks over to the cash register of this neighborhood corner store; and Easy follows, the drunk beckoning him t bend down to talk as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, brother help me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry 'bout him. I rung Junior ten minutes ago to come get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy pulls out two dollars and Hattie deposits them into till.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't got nobody tonight but Lips and his trio -- Holiday came through here last Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy FOOTSTEPS are heard pounding down a stairway in the back of the store and big burly JUNIOR FORNAY lumbers in with a cigarette hanging from his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's he at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hattie points to the drunk man as he struggles to get to feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over there. Let Easy in upstairs and when these cops leave throw his ass out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Junior.    What's goin' on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too much.    But stick around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior leads the way back up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls out his pack and stops to light Easy up.   Easy starts coughing as they continue up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn! How do you smoke these things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you hafta work tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw.    I got fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hint of a smile appears on Junior's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last time I heard these fellas playin' tonight was back in Houston, the night your ole buddy Mouse had to pull me up off your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy grins and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way you remember it, hunh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, that's the way it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he stops to unlock the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) When you gonna admit that you helped Mouse kill old man Navrochet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, man, get off that. I ain't had nothin' to do with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior opens the door and Lips' alto horn slaps Easy in t face. Half of Houston, Texas seems to be jammed into this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, it's happenin' tonight. Where's all the white women at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't pay them white girls no mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Yeah... I bet you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Just like you didn't help mouse kill his stepfather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he starts away inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Easy. Did you help him kill his stepbrother, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy turns to glare at Junior and the surly field hand sl his thigh and roars with laughter as he closes the door. After all these years the two men still hate each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy looks around to see couples trying to dance; finding themselves wrestling between tables packed with five and people each. He heads for the bar pointing a finger at a man in a blac silk shirt and a foot-high pompadour hairdo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alphonso Jenkins!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALPHONSO flashes pearls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Easy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man, you seen a girl named Dahlia or somethin'... White girl supposed to be somethin' to look at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, but if I see her I'm gonna keep her to myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy claps him on the shoulder and waves at skinny RITA C who is sitting at a table with five MEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Rita! (under his breath) What do they see in you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Easy spots a fifty-year-old MAN in an old grey tweed jacket sitting in a corner at a table by himself. Looking like the God fearing, all fearing Baptist deacon that he is -- he is as out of place as a whore in church he nervously gazes about the room and massacres a plate o barbecued ribs. Easy leans over the counter to the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Lewis. Gimme a couple glasses and a pail of ice and send a quart of bourbon over there to Odell's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis scoops up ice into a small bucket and plops it onto the bar with two short glasses. Easy lays a dollar on the counter and carries the set up over to the corner as he watches...

dialogues.speaker: THE BAND
dialogues.text: burn it up.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Easy stops at Odell's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Odell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odell doesn't miss a bite as he scopes the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) Well... It's goin' alright.   It sure is goin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy Rawlins, is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy looks up to see DUPREE, a big black man with a wide white grin in a white suite with blue pinstripes and a ten-gallon hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't jumped outta no windows yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet, Dupree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss you down at the plant... You know Coretta, don't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has her in tow like a toy wagon and she offers a coy smile. Short and roundish with cherry-brown skin, she lea with her bosom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Coretta, how are ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coretta rests her sloe-eyes on Easy and Odell and the chu going man almost chokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my goodness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could we sit down with y'all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.   Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dupree and Coretta settle in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Benny just wants you to say you're sorry, Easy. And he'll give you your job back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a sorry man, all right. Any man without his paycheck is sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dupree laughs, smacking the table so hard it rattles like earthquake. And Coretta's smile ignites like a slow fuse causing Easy to feel it all the way down his spine. A man with his hair marcelled back swoops in and pulls a quart of Old Crow from his overcoat and sits it on the table. Easy reaches for his wallet but Dupree beats him to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it, Easy. Your money ain't no good up in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, Dupree.    This one's mine--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?   You the one outta work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coretta frowns at Dupree as Easy counts out three dollars

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're the one ain't never got no money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, Baby... (to bootlegger) Get us another couple glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he peels off a dollar and hands it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either one of y'all seen a white girl named Dahlia or somethin' with a 'D'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odell shakes his head "no," and Coretta looks away as if insulted leaving silence until

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Coretta got a new job at the phone company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He squeezes his woman in close and Coretta softens up and burns that smile again. Easy grins and nods "congratulations."

dialogues.speaker: THE BOTTLE
dialogues.text: It's less than a quarter full now because it's three hour later.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: John's is only half full and the band is gone. The jukebo echoes Lena Horne's "Prisoner of Love" and Dupree leans b in his chair, snoring -- mouth wide open. Odell gets up and starts to amble off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you goin' home, Odell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concentrating totally on keeping his balance, Odell waves feebly without looking back. Easy is droopy-eyed from the booze but Coretta just looks little sexier. She straightens Dupree's hat on his head a twists up her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He used to play till the cock crowed. But that ole cock don't crow nearly so much now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She levels her perpetual "come on" onto Easy and he nods sluggishly and lifts himself to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think I'm gonna head out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You be sorry if you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slides her hand inside her blouse and discreetly lift her bodice to air her breasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'd be more sorry if I stay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daphne sleep by now. You can't get none of that tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy turns and Coretta plays with the ice in her glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been telling everybody Dahlia, but her name is Daphne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know her?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Coretta leans back and fans her bosom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy struggles with Dupree, and Coretta gives him a hand they drag him from Easy's car to her front door, the big man's feet plowing two deep furrows in the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coretta pushes the door open and Easy hauls him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw him in there on the bed, Easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy pulls and pushes Dupree's dead weight into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throwed him outta his place, 'cause he couldn't pay the rent. I shouldn't even let him sleep here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally Easy manages to pile Dupree onto the bed and then stands up panting and sweating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coretta leads him out into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coretta shines her hazel eyes on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That all you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy grins nervously and clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coretta, sun catch me tip-toein' out your door and no tellin' what your neighbors say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dupree run through his money, fall asleep on me. And you just gonna walk out on me like I was dog food...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a man in the other room... Why don't you tell me 'bout your friend Daphne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coretta strolls up to Easy, pressing her body against his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you keep askin' 'bout her? Colored women ain't good enough for you no more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She undoes a button on his shirt and kisses his chest, an unbuttons another working her way down. Easy sweats harde than when he was lifting Dupree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if he hears somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way he snorin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, daddy. You hittin' my spot! Oh yeah... yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The top of her dress undone, Coretta is straddling Easy w is hitting her spot and his too, in a rhythm. Eyes closed, he bites his lip to hold in the ecstasy so as not awaken Dupree, who is sawing logs -- shredding 'em -- in bedroom. Suddenly Coretta tears herself off of him and sits back o his knees. Easy writhes and shakes like a power line shorting out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coy, shy) Oooh, that's just too good, Easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy tries to pull her back but she twists down to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't give up that much love, daddy, not the way things is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out loud) What things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shushes him with a finger and twists her head toward bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Dupree's right there in the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (full voice) Forget about him! You got me goin', Coretta!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coretta quiets him again and he comes back to his senses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it ain't right, Easy. Here I am doin' this right in the next room and all you doin' is nosin' after my friend Daphne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daphne? (and then remembers) Oh, yeah... I ain't after her, baby. That's just a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man wants me to find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares, what man?   I don't want nobody but you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her toward him but she pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Daphne's my friend--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frustrated, he sits back against the sofa and Coretta, sensing that he is snapping out of her spell, slides forw onto him giving him her spot again. And within moments they are back at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, baby. Oh, daddy, you hittin' my spot! Oh, yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went on hittin' her spot until just before sun-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is light purple as Easy stumbles down Coretta's porch. She waves half-heartedly and closes the door as he straightens his clothes and looks around for any "witness on his way to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy's Pontiac pulls to a stop in front and he gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It occurred to me that Coretta had found out a lot more about what I was up to than I had wanted her to. But I had found out that the rich man's woman had a colored boyfriend... It had cost me a sawbuck to get Coretta to give me that information... Well, let's just say somethin' had cost me ten dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Golden morning light streams in through the window. Outside, a dog is barking at a bird on the fence. Coffee percolates on the stove and Easy walks over and po himself a cup. He moves to the breakfast table and sits down by the window looking out onto the street as he open up a blue envelope in a stack of mail. Gradually he begins to silently mouth the words and sits his eyes getting bigger until he finds himself reading aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Since Etta Mae has left me and I am a bachelor I figured I could come out and visit and we burn down the town...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write me and tell me when's a good time." (looks up) Aw shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy waters his lawn in deep thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The letter from Mouse was worrying me in more ways than one... All I had to do was call Albright to earn the hundred dollars I already had in my pocket... But the last time I got money that easy I got it from Mouse -- fifty dollars -- And the next day I had to join the Army to leave town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A younger Easy is driving, his hair greased up high in a pompadour with a pencil line moustache framing his top li A man in a wide brim Homburg hat looks away out the passenger window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drive to the trainyard, Easy! Let's dump this damn thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly alarmed) This ain't your friend's car? What'd you do Mouse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still looking away) Just drive this sumbitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drone of the engine takes us

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: A TRUCK with a whole family's belongings tied down onto a flatbed rolls up. A WOMAN and a bunch of KIDS fill up the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, Easy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you goin', Sophie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to Texas... It's too fast for me out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waves and keeps on trucking. He watches her wistfully and then catches sight of THE WOODCUTTER across the street in a neighbor's front ya axe in hand, about to swing on a lemon tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up a rock and throws it, and then chucks another sending the scruffy vagabond wheeling his barrow off down the street. Easy shuts off the water and walks back up on his porch. picks up a glass of lemonade that sits at the foot of a chair on top of

dialogues.speaker: A NEWSPAPER
dialogues.text: A front page heading reads "CARTER'S WITHDRAWAL LEAVES TE ON TOP." Below it A PHOTOGRAPH of a smiling Matthew Teran, with lips too th for a white man, getting out of a limousine. 31   O.S. THE PHONE IS RINGING.    It's

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Easy is asleep on the porch. Finally, he wakes up to the ringing and heads into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy flops on the bed and lifts the phone off a cherry wo nightstand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rawlins, I've been expecting your call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you have good news for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Albright, is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure is, Easy. What's shakin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy clears his head.    He has slept away the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got what you want.   She's with--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on to that, Easy. I like to look a man in the face when we do business. Meet me at the Fisherman's Pier in Malibu at the hamburger stand in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... I don't know about that Mr. Albright -- Mr. Albright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He realizes that Albright has hung up, and swears under h breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headlights from Easy's car illuminate the cliffs that fall alongside the winding two-lane highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy is cautious, checking the rearview mirror more often than usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't used to going to white communities, like Malibu, to conduct business. Champion Aircraft was in Santa Monica but I drove out there in the daytime, did my work and came home. I never loitered nowhere except among my own people, in my own neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights from the   pier can be seen in the distance as parks his car. And    the voices of teenagers in raucous conversation can be   heard above Glenn Miller's big band playing "Silhouette   In The Moonlight" on the jukebox.

dialogues.speaker: A35 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Easy gets out and starts toward the pier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy walks past the hamburger stand and on to the railing that looks out over the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spins around and sees a chubby 17-year-old white GIRL a tight-fitting skirt. He nods respectfully and turns away to look out at the water, hoping she'll leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pretty out here, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm from Des Moines in Iowa.    Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking back) Huh?... Uh... Texas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they have an ocean in Texas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gulf, they have the Gulf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans on the rail next to Easy and he glances over hi shoulder, seeing a couple of the young men looking around like they've lost someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they're looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares? My sister brought me 'cause my parents made her. All she wants to do is make out with Herman and smoke cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you!   What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five-foot-six-inch twenty-year-old charges straight u to Easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Leave him alone, Herman!   We were just talking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were, huh? (to Easy) We don't need you talking to our women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy braces himself as five of Herman's FRIENDS rush over including one built like a football player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!   What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nigger's trying to pick up Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave him alone! We were just talking about the ocean!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Football gets right in Easy's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, fella, what's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of the other boys have picked up sticks and are surrounding Easy against the rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want no trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already got trouble, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen... I was just being polite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you weren't. You were talkin' about the ocean!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy sees Albright's Panama hat appear behind Football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he whirls around to Albright's smiling face, just in time to see him pull that rifle-like pistol from inside h coat, leveling it at his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see brains.    I want you to die for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albright cocks the hammer. It sounds like a bone breaking and Barbara starts crying in her sister's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) I'm sorry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy nods but Albright is not satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question is: "Are you sorry enough?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then prove it... Show him... Get down on your knees and suck his peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Football starts crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Albright) I think he got the point--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Football) You heard me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses the barrel to the boy's forehead and Football goes down to his knees. The other young men look on in horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a gun. You were gonna do it, weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNK! He slaps the barrel of the pistol into the side of the boy's head. Football screams and the others scatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sick bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNK!   He smacks him again, and blood is everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here. You call the cops, I'll kill ya!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Football manages to stagger to his feet and stumbles away into the darkness back out toward the parking lot. 36   Albright wipes his gun with a handkerchief and slide back into the holster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think they'd dare call the cops. (giggles) But it'll cost me a few bucks if they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He claps Easy on the back as if it's all been in fun and giggles like a kid on his way toward the hamburger stand. Easy looks at him numbly and tags alongside, clutching hi anger in tightly clenched jaws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you got, Easy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure no harm is gonna come to that woman 'cause of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albright doesn't break stride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course not. Mr. Carter wants to buy her a gold ring and live happily ever after -- What do ya got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy exhales, feeling trapped, but he's come this far...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woman told me she's with a man named Frank Green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albright stops; the charm gone, he's all business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got an apartment at the Skyler Arms on Skyler and Eighty-third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albright scribbles it down on a note pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's a gangster. A hijacker... Liquor and cigarettes. He's real good with a knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albright is unable to suppress a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever seen him in action?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw.   I just heard about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albright, still grinning, pulls out the brown "secretary" and counts out more bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's another hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoves the money into Easy's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy ya a burger, Easy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts into the screen door of the hamburger stand but Easy declines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, Mr. Albright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you let those boys get around you like that? War hero should have been able to pick 'em off one by one before they got you against the rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't kill children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For some reason this is hilarious to Albright. He throws his head back and wheezes out an almost silent belly laug then winds down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He disappears into the hamburger joint and Easy walks awa back toward his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy pulls in front of his house and notices a dark Ford parked across the street as he gets out of his car. A tall, skinny white MAN in a dark blue suit gets out jus ahead of his slightly shorter and heavyset FRIEND. Easy watches them as he moves toward his walkway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rawlins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach fast but cautiously, the fat one with a han in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rawlins, I'm Miller and this is my partner, Mason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both hold out badges. Mason is a slob with grease spots on his wrinkled tan suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want you to come with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he takes Easy by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You arresting me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he starts pulling Easy toward the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a right to know why you're taking--

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WHOMP! Easy takes one to the diaphragm, and as he doubles over the fat detective slips the handcuffs on behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a right to fall down and break your face, nigger. You got a right to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two cops drag Easy to the car and dump him into the b seat where he lies gagging as the car whisks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy's head sags down as he's dragged through the front d past blurred blue bodies that talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got 'im, huh, Miller?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we got him coming home. Nothing on 'im.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door opens and Easy finds himself being flung inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his knees he hears the door close and looks up at a single, bare wooden chair resting on the corroded linoleu floor. He crawls to one of the urine-stained corners, and looks on a dry, flat corpse of a mouse. He pushes his shoulder against the unpainted plaster until he's standing and the stumbles over to the chair and sits. He looks up at the bare pipes that run along the ceiling, dripping water, an at a window with criss-cross chairs instead of glass fram overgrown branches and leaves pushing their way in. THE DOOR opens and Miller comes in first carrying a notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ezekiel Rawlins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason follows and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can take off the cuffs if you wanna cooperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm cooperating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller motions to Mason and he removes the cuffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you this morning at about five A.M.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stalling) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He means--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plants his foot in Easy's chest and pushes him over backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy has caught himself and stands back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I was out drinkin' and I helped carry a friend home. I could've been on my way home... I don't know... I didn't look at a clock...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wandering over) He didn't look at a clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHOCK! Easy takes a fist to the ear and struggles to keep his balance, wiping away blood streaming down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were drinkin' down on Eighty- ninth and Central... At an illegal club called John's, weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason moves again but this time Easy turns to face him an the fat man looks back with an innocent face, his palms turned up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may as well answer 'cause you got bigger troubles than us bustin' an illegal bar, Ezekiel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?    What's goin' on?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mason has taken off his shoe and is swatting it against t palm of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Means we can take your black ass out behind the station and put a bullet in your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. What time did you leave Coretta James' house this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess about five... five- thirty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller and Mason glance at each other, and Mason kicks th chair over toward Easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, I'm gonna sit down and you keep trying to knock me down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he sits down anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you go back and see Miss James later in the day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you and Dupree Brouchard have words over Miss James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard 'im. Did you two argue over Coretta James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw.   He was asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She went to sleep too, Ezekiel. But she won't be waking up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy's face goes sick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where'd you go when you left Miss James' house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy is too stunned to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard him, where'd you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy stares into space, answering in barely a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went home with a hangover...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHOONK! CHOONK! Mason fires off two punches and Easy grab his wrists and pulls him down to the floor, swinging arou straddling Mason sitting on his ass... Miller's police special presses into Easy's temple and Miller speaks to him quietly, deadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up slow... Real fuckin' slow or you know what's gonna happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy raises his hands and uncoils to his feet, backing aw cautiously. Mason is winded and furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   Let's take him out back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets to his feet and reaches for his gun, but Miller stops his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit, I'm gonna blow his--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes Mason toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son-of-a-bitch! Son-of-a-bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit the door and Easy rubs at his bloody ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy walks down the steps of the station buttoning up his top shirt button, his hand cupped to his aching ear to ke out the chill of the night air. The street is dark and deserted like a giant black alley except for the black and white patrol car that sits at th curb. A taut-faced officer leans out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Buddy!... It's a long walk... why don't you let us give you a ride? Easy walks across the street off into the darkness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A snatch of MUSIC and LAUGHTER startles Easy as he trudge home and a car full of teenagers shoots by. And then...

dialogues.speaker: A BLACK CADILLAC LIMOUSINE
dialogues.text: cruises up behind and drives alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you!   Ezekiel Rawlins! The window rolls down all the way and a white face in a black cap appears in the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ezekiel, hold on. Easy keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, fella. Somebody in the back wants to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have time right now. He doubles his pace, almost running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jump in. We'll take you.    My boss wants to talk to you. Easy cuts behind the limo and into the street headed for other side of the bridge but

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Cadillac whips a U-turn blocking his way in the middl of the street while cars pass, honking, on either side. T tall angular chauffeur gets out of the car and holds up h hands as if making peace. Easy starts to make another move to escape but:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Come on. If we wanted to hurt you it would have already happened...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the back door and after a few moments, Easy gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy settles into the seat with his back to the driver. Edith Piaf's "Parles Moi D'Amour" adds sugar to the stron smell of cologne and the portly form of Matthew Teran sit across from him with a small MEXICAN BOY in pajamas seate next to him holding a small elephant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see that the police roughed you up a bit... That's a terrible practice of theirs which has to change, Mr. Rawlins... Has to change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens his gold cigarette case and offers Easy a cigarette. Easy accepts and Teran lights them both up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) She was beaten. And died from a heavy blow to the back of the head, Mr. Rawlins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy begins to feel nauseous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The evening's events have caught my adopted son and I quite off guard... My household was asleep when we got the call that the police had a suspect in Coretta James' murder... Did you know that she was a friend of mine, Mr. Rawlins!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I didn't, Mr. Teran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read the papers.   You're runnin' for mayor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (correcting) I am the next mayor, Mr. Rawlins... And luckily for you, a friend of the Negro... When I arrived at the station I knew right off that you were being improperly detained as is Coretta's boyfriend, Dupree Brouchard. It's this sort of thing that my administration will not tolerate, Mr. Rawlins. Absolutely will not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits back in his seat self righteously and offers a no of assurance and awaits Easy's gratitude... Then after a moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Yes... Coretta answered phones for a while in my campaign office on 103rd and Western. In fact my people got her a job in the phone company. So when I heard what had happened I got out of bed immediately, personally because of my concern... Was anyone there with you Mr. Rawlins besides Mr. Dupree Brouchard?... Any... other friends of Coretta's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No young lady perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not, Mr. Rawlins. And why should you tell a man whom you've only just met. But, believe me, Mr. Rawlins. You can trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) There was no one else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teran's face sags with disappointment and then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well don't worry, Mr. Rawlins... I won't tolerate your being harassed... You or any of my constituency -- I was a city councilman in the Watts area for two terms with a large contingent of colored -- I value all of my supporters equally... humble though they may be -- where can we drop you, Mr. Rawlins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can let me out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure, Mr. Rawlins? This must be quite out of your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little boy stares up at Easy through big, dark almond shaped eyes in the silence that follows. And then, Teran picks up the ivory horn that hangs next to his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman, pull the car over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine stops and Easy pushes the door open and get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rawlins, may I offer you cab fare?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teran's stubby fingers hold out crumpled bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy closes the door and watches the long Cadillac glide away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There had been nights during the war that I still had trouble claiming as part of my life... Insane nights I wasn't sure ever really happened. And here I was again... Had I really just gotten out of a rich man's car who was runnin' for mayor?.. Running against the man I was supposed to be working for... Was he really lookin' for the same woman I was trying to find? My ear was killin' me and the buses had stopped running. And I was feeling sick... Sick from wondering if I had really hard that Coretta was dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is a mess; trousers strewn here, shirt and shoes over there. And from the corners are haunting, ghostly whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You be sorry if you go... (heavy breathing) I can't give up that much love, daddy, not the way things is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PINT OF BOURBON, 3/4 full, sits atop the cherry wood nightstand. Another empty bottle lies next to it on its side, in front of a water glass with 1/2 inch of liquor a the bottom. EASY'S HEAD rests on a pillow on the bed behind it, sweating, tossing and turning as the ghost gets louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, daddy. You hittin' my spot... Oh yeah... oh yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice of the ghost is reaching closer for his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's just too good, Easy.   Oh daddy... oh yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice is right up in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, baby. Oh, daddy, yeah... Oh yeah!! Oh Yea-a-h!!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SCREAM. He jerks up, awake, and the phone is RINGING. jingles a couple more times and Easy almost knocks the receiver out of its cradle reaching for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a woman's) Hello? Is this Mr. Rawlins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daphne... Daphne Monet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits straight up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should come and talk to me, Mr. Rawlins... alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's late--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rawlins, Coretta has been killed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you don't want any trouble from the police then you'll come... And you won't tell anyone that you're coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute, Daphne. I don't know nothin' about all this stuff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm at the Sunridge Motel on 112th and Grand, Room 102.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Easy holds his hands up, helplessly -- "what do you want from me?" -- but no one can see and she has hung up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a Spanish-style set of rooms with tile roofs set aro a square parking lot. Easy's car pulls into the alley behind it. He gets out and scans the area looking down from a rise a the back entrance to the parking lot. And then walks down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Easy can knock, he hears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rawlins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and she's standing there, more beautiful t the photograph. They take each other in for a moment befo she steps back from the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a regular drab, cheap motel that she has given a war touch with colorful scarves draped over the two lamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She indicates a pint of scotch on the dresser with an emp glass and one that she's been drinking from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She indicates the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's wearing a blue dress that's plain, cutting just bel her knee with a ceramic pin just over her left breast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to you?   Have you been fighting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy stubs out his cigarette in an ashtray and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just tell me what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down too, her calm but brittle exterior betrayed the hands. She stops wringing them when she sees that he notices and takes a drink -- more medicine than pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be asking you that question. Why have you been asking about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard about you. Fellas at John's said you were something to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...?   You've found me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... yeah... Guess I have. But you got a boyfriend I don't want no part of... Frank Green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can stop pretending, Mr. Rawlins. I know someone hired you to look for me. In fact I had to pay Coretta not to tell you where I was... you know how Coretta is... (forces a weak smile) She told me you two became 'good friends' yesterday... (tears gather in her eyes) I talked to her this morning before she died. (regaining control) I... uh... need to go across town to see someone. It's very important... I can't seem to reach him by phone. I'm afraid I'd better have someone go with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... Miss Monet--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Daphne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daphne--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can understand why you'd be nervous... because I threatened you with Coretta... I'm very sorry, but I couldn't think of any other way to get you to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes another drink and stubs out her cigarette thoug it's less than a third gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't -- why don't you ask Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up and starts to pace nervously about the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's out of town -- I... I'm willing to pay you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice of you but, see, I'm not really a detective--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --I know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just hired to ask around to try to find you for a man--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know all about that, Mr. Rawlins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is a gettin' a little out of hand--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Mr. Rawlins--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy... If you don't help me, then I'll call the police and tell them that you were with Coretta before she died and that you've been after me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That stops Easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I would.    I don't want to but I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hates herself for threatening and decides to change direction, moving in close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please let me pay you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.    I can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want no part of all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, I'll pay you twenty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No dice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty... or even more.    Name your price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves in closer, massaging with her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Go ahead. There's gotta be something that you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes make an offer, but he's a better man than me and he's not taking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily, sarcastically) What? Are you afraid I'll yell rape or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks away and turns up her glass, her desperation, r unguarded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Miss Monet... Daphne, I'm sorry but I really better be goin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts out and she runs to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, don't touch that door--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens it and SCREAM!   Like an alarm, she's SHRIEKING all of the scale 49   He looks out and sees LIGHTS GOING ON in other rooms.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: He looks back frantically and grabs her by the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy assed broad!   What the hell are you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really very sorry.   I really am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls on a coat and grabs her purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I didn't want to do this but... Shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs an already packed suitcase and is out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy's Pontiac snakes up the winding road, city lights glimmering in flashes below as it rounds the curves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Webster's "I've   Got It Bad" plays on the road as Ea shifts nervously in   his seat, his eyes searching in the rearview mirror and   all around for headlights that migh unfriendly. Daphne    leans back against the passenger do taking him in. Easy passes a police car pulled over to the side. He looks in the rearview mirror and its headlights go on. He takes a deep breath, bracing for the worst and Daphne looks back concerned. But the lights arch a U-turn and head back the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must not have seen us that well... God, Frank and I have been pulled over so many times I thought-- She catches herself and looks over at Easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, I'm sorry... Don't be mad at me. Easy keeps his eyes on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. She tries to touch his arm and he pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really hate me, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much further is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the next bend... (she grins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remind me of Frank when he gets angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't nothin' about me like Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your jaw sets just like his when--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get no kick outta risking my life for some white woman's entertainment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing) Just park behind the Studebaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Studebaker is parked at a deadend in the street.    E pulls in behind. The cabin is so overgrown with ivy that all this is visib is the mailbox and address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you bring a gun or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, that's not very smart. Everybody carries a weapon now a days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively) Well then where's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Search me sometime.   You'll find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He frowns and gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
